text: one of the best boss themes
author: Wenceslao Futanaki

text: The only thing I can hear when this is playing is the 'wheop' sound of a healing spell being used.
author: IdleBigots

text: The only thing and I mean the only thing I didn't particularly like about this game was the walking speed in the overworld and towers/dungeons/caves. They at least could've sold you some Sprint Shoes or something to make you walk faster. I know there are hacks that make it to where you can, but to me not fooling around with something in some cases is better, but this is not one of those cases.
author: Junior

text: Especially with how enormous and maze-like some of the game's dungeons are, the walking speed becomes your worst enemy. Well, that and the lack of save points in dungeons that can take an hour to get through only to die to a boss at the end.
author: gurvmlk

text: Walking speed wasn't that bad to me...the ultra high encounter rate was though.
author: diamondlancer

text:
My main complaint is that game's plot just moves WAY too slow.  Just when it's about to pick up steam, you get bogged down in fetch quests or have to complete a random task that's off the beaten path before proceeding.  After a while, it's simply INFURIATING.

The music, after all these years, still kicks ass though :)
author: AJR 1986

text: Can you enter this cave through another entrance so you can supervise our work on the bridge from that ledge over there?
author: diamondlancer

text: Reminds me the first time I fought against revived Gades, I was like "Holy shit!". I didn't know I was supposed to lose until the battle ended.
author: The Cat Who Saw You Naked

text: Man, you know you're old when you remember when "Battery back-up" was an advertised feature in a game :P  I'm an old man!
author: AJR 1986

text: You know you're an even older man when you remember when passwords were an advertised feature in a game. XP
author: gurvmlk

text: Try remembering when you had to blow into cartridges to make them work.
author: Christian McNellie

text: @Christian McNellie I still play my NES to this day, so that's not something I need to try very hard to remember (although nowadays I usually clean them properly since I know better).
author: gurvmlk

text: @gurvmlk That's the thing, now you know better methods. What were things like for you about 25 years ago?
author: Christian McNellie

text: @Christian McNellie Acceptance for complications far beyond what spoiled kids nowadays with all their functional electronics could ever imagine tolerating.
author: gurvmlk

text: @gurvmlk I hear what you're saying man! Some of my cousins don't even know what the NES was.
author: Christian McNellie

text: @Christian McNellie One night a few years ago, one of my cousin's sons was staying the night. He pointed at my NES on my dresser and asked, "What's that?" Granted it made perfect sense because of his young age (he was only like 6 or 7), it was still one of the hardest to hear questions anybody has ever addressed to me.
author: gurvmlk

text: @gurvmlk It was because he is very young. Don't take it so hard, you're just getting older. I get it, he probably doesn't know how hard most videogames used to be either.
author: Christian McNellie

text: @Christian McNellie"Game Over? What's that?" XP
author: gurvmlk

text: @gurvmlk LOL!!!
author: Christian McNellie

text: "Stereo Sound" used to be a point of pride.
author: Ragitsu

text: When I was young, I used to think it was awesome when a game or movie would be in stereo, and I didn't even know what stereo was. All I knew is that it was better than mono, so I got excited over it.
author: gurvmlk

text: When I had originally watched the final seasons (re-runs?) of MacGyver as a wee lad, I saw that those in charge of the show put up a notification of "In Stereo where available." Now, I pay attention to see if a video game supports 5.1 or even 7.1 sound...which was once only a feature of big Hollywood productions 8-^D.
author: Ragitsu

text: I didn't even know 7.1 was a thing. Every time I think of 5.1 though, I can't not hear that loud, horn-like sound that would always play at the theatre when the Dolby logo popped up before the movie. You'd hear that, and be like, "Shit just got amazing."
author: gurvmlk

text: I know passwords because of GBA being my first

author: Ben Fischer

text: Because the first part of the game, you're controlling the original heroes just before their final fight against the Sinistrals.
author: chepepuy

text: +chepepuy Something that, in most games, would merely be referred to as backstory.
author: gurvmlk

text: It's similar to the beginning of Tales of Phantasia, except in this case you control the characters.
author: Christian McNellie

text: You basically play the prologue.  Most games it would be a cinematic.  But this is one of the first RPGs (that I can think of) which allows you to take control of the character's in the prologue.
author: AJR 1986

text: and it's almost impossible to mess up too funnily enough

text: sucks that a lot of great rpg games on the snes, were never released here in Europe. =( the only way to play them on a snes is to get an adapter, or to play on emulator.
author: bazla123

text: It's not put in the clearest way, but it's referring to how at the start of the game, you get to take part in a climactic battle against the Sinistrals, as opposed to having to level grind to even go into the first dungeon. While the game got boring for me soon after the actual game began, that was a nice touch that set it apart from other RPGs.

text:
Unlike previous RPGs this one includes a battery-backup system!

Fun series, no doubt.

author: fishluv [pop'n music]

text:
Some thoughts:

This song has 3 strains, 2 of which are the same. So you might say the structure is AAB. Does anyone get the feeling like the song should continue at 1:04 into a 4th strain? (AABC)

Lufia 2's boss battle theme is also divided into 3 strains, ABC. As with Lufia 1's, I get the feeling that it's too short. Seriously, 3 strains? How weird is that? But, Lufia 2's 3rd strain actually resolves, and leads into the 1st strain well. It's also a much more interesting theme than Lufia 1's.
